instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Liquid damage around <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>. Replaced: <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7741</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>. Just a tiny bit of soy sauce got near this chip. Ultrasoniced.

<CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR> 5V
<CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR> 3.3V
<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>-1 8.57V
<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>-2 2.8V
<RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> 1.46V
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE>-1 8.5V
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE>-2 21V
Lid 3.4V

New LCD assembly same.
PRAM Reseted
Image present

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: No boost occurring, check feedback line.

threads.message:
So what should it be boosting to?
& what should <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> be?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: it should be 25-27v. <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> should be 3.3v you can try taking a jumper from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> to the <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> that will set it on full brightness permanently

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: After a PRAM reset should be about 3V on <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> (full brightness), on boosting I have 26V.........  I say bad backlight driver, but also check connector.....

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Probably the <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> then?  I've been using pulled ones reballed with an iPhone stencil. I have some on order, but impatient.  Thanx Philip, I'll try this jumper ! 

And thank you for clarifying the voltages ! ! !

<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: Replace <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> before doing anything at this point.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: Rodger that.  I actually found another <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> I'm going to try. Jumping PWM with 3V did nothing.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: 3rd <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. Same results.  All of these come off donor boards though.  I may have to wait until the new ones come.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
I had similar issue with another board, if iset or fset (I don't remember witch one) are open, I mean open/blown <RESISTOR>R7716</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R7714</RESISTOR>, bad trace or bad soldering on B3 and B4 <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> balls, bcklt output will be stuck (by default?) at something like 21v. Fset is what set the PWM frequency.it's different from one screen to another. Iset probably has to do with current setting depending on the led screen 11"13"15"
Check the values and trace continuity between <RESISTOR>R7716</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7714</RESISTOR> and ground,  <RESISTOR>R7716</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7714</RESISTOR> and <CHIP>LP5880</CHIP>.
